Fashion, bright arbitress supreme,</br>Whilst I thy praise rehearse,</br>And make thy magic pow'r my theme,</br>O stamp thy sanction on my verse!</br>Then, tho' uncouth it roll along,</br>Like some rude crier's ill-rhim'd song,</br>Devoid of harmony and ease;</br>Still, bless'd by thee, my lays shall please.</br>Thy vot'ries, then, with raptures near divine,</br>Shall praise the charming thought, and sweet harmonious line.

Should'st thou refuse thy potent aid,</br>Tho' Milton's thought be there,</br>And imag'ry like his display'd,</br>Still must the sighing bard despair;</br>No tongue shall yield him honest praise,</br>Nor pretty Misses read his lays:</br>In vain, poor fellow!  must he write;</br>In vain essay to give delight;</br>Unless thy fame bestowing hand, O Ton!</br>With friendly aid should deign to consecrate his song.

On earth thy influence is such,</br>So absolute thy sway,</br>That, by thy all-commanding touch,</br>We swear, and lye, and preach, and pray.</br>Revers'd, by thee thou magic sprite,</br>Shall right be wrong, and wrong be right;</br>Deform'd shall Beauty's self appear,</br>And discord charm the ravish'd ear;</br>By thee shall dulness triumph, in despite</br>Of what declaimers say, or monthly critics write.

By thee, O'Keefe, with trite old pun,</br>Shall meet the applauding roar</br>Of those who hail him Humour's son,</br>And crown him with a loud encore:</br>By thee his thrice-told obscene jest,</br>Tho' in the coarsest language drest,</br>Aided by Edwin's comic faces,</br>Shall boast a multitude of graces;</br>Grimace and jargon pass for sterling wit,</br>And senseless ribaldry be deem'd "a damn good hit."

Like thee, with absolute command,</br>Once superstition reign'd;</br>And over Egypt's fertile land,</br>A long unrivall'd sway maintain'd:</br>As then Religion's name she bore,</br>Deluded millions own'd her pow'r;</br>She render'd sacred ev'ry sod,</br>And rais'd each trifle to a god;</br>Bade Egypt's sons, as ignorant as meek,</br>Sing hymns to unions, and adore a leek.</br>
